rev.comment: /* Response */ collapse refs into one tag
rev.diff:
Line 6: Line 6:
==Response==
==Response==
â
[[Laura Flanders]] described the events as a "[[Bull Connor]] Moment", in reference to the Birmingham, Alabama leader who infamously deployed firehoses and attack dogs against peaceful protestors during the [[American Civil Rights Movement]]<ref>[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/eyesontheprize/story/07_c.html PBS's Eyes on the Prize segment, including video of Connor.]</ref><ref>[http://www2.nbc13.com/vtm/news/local/article/bull_connors_tank_returns_to_birmingham/39865/ Connor's Tank Returns to Birmingham]</ref><ref>Laura Flanders, Nov 19, 2011 "Up with Chris Hayes"</ref> University Professor [[Bob Ostertag]] echoed these sentiments in public letter, writing:<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bob-ostertag/uc-davis-protest_b_1103039.html Militarization of Campus Police]</ref>
+
[[Laura Flanders]] described the events as a "[[Bull Connor]] Moment", in reference to the Birmingham, Alabama leader who infamously deployed firehoses and attack dogs against peaceful protestors during the [[American Civil Rights Movement]].<ref>[http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/eyesontheprize/story/07_c.html PBS's Eyes on the Prize segment, including video of Connor.][http://www2.nbc13.com/vtm/news/local/article/bull_connors_tank_returns_to_birmingham/39865/ Connor's Tank Returns to Birmingham]; Laura Flanders, Nov 19, 2011 "Up with Chris Hayes"</ref> University Professor [[Bob Ostertag]] echoed these sentiments in public letter, writing:<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bob-ostertag/uc-davis-protest_b_1103039.html Militarization of Campus Police]</ref>
{{quote|"Chancellor Robert Birgeneau thus joins the likes of Bull Connor, the notorious segregationist and architect of the violent repression of the civil rights movement in Birmingham, Alabama, as some of the very few people who view the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King as violent." }}
{{quote|"Chancellor Robert Birgeneau thus joins the likes of Bull Connor, the notorious segregationist and architect of the violent repression of the civil rights movement in Birmingham, Alabama, as some of the very few people who view the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King as violent." }}
